title: More than 1,200 migrants arrive to Britain on small boats in just three days
body:
More than 1,200 small boat migrants have arrived in Britain in just three days, marking a return to levels not seen since last year.

The Home Office yesterday confirmed 545 migrants reached the UK across the Channel on Monday, after 703 over the weekend.

It means levels are at their highest since the end of November.

At least four more boat loads thought to be carrying about 200 people were brought into Dover by Border Force vessels yesterday.

It came as the United Nations warned that 110million people globally have been displaced from their homes.

More than 1,200 small boat migrants have arrived in Britain in just three days, marking a return to levels not seen since last year. Pictured: A group of men about to be taken on board a Border Force vessel on Sunday

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) said in a new report that numbers had surged by more than 20million since its last estimates.

The agency's total covered people displaced by 'war, persecution, violence and human rights abuses'.

Its estimates said there are more than 35million refugees who have fled their home nations, including 5.7million Ukrainians who have fled Vladimir Putin's bloody war.

A further 62.5million people globally have been displaced within their own countries.

Numbers are continuing to rise due to instability in Somalia and Sudan, in particular, the UNHCR said.

Ministers here in Britain, including Home Secretary Suella Braverman, have said the global number of migrants is directly linked to those who end up attempting to cross the Channel.

The UNHCR said the UK was one of 92 countries to see an increase in its asylum processing backlog last year, while 43 other countries saw a fall.

The surge across the Channel came as peers complained they have been 'abused, bullied and intimidated' by the Government over a new package of immigration measures.

Following a late night session last week, the House of Lords sat until after 2am yesterday debating the Illegal Migration Bill. Lib Dem peer Baroness Ludford said the package had received 'almost no scrutiny' in the Commons.

'When we do try to do it we are abused, bullied and intimidated as we were until 4.20am last Thursday,' she said.

'It would be perfectly possible to have a... more rational timetable for this Bill.

'I do not appreciate the behaviour of the Government over this Bill.'

The Home Office yesterday confirmed 545 migrants reached the UK across the Channel on Monday, after 703 over the weekend

Labour peer Baroness Lister complained in the chamber she was 'shaking with tiredness'. But Tory peer Lord Hodgson told the opposition: 'We would move forward a great deal faster if we hadn't had so many repetitious speeches.'

The Bill, which has already been through the Commons, aims to ensure those arriving in the UK without permission are detained and promptly deported, either to their home country or a third country such as Rwanda.

Critics argue the draft legislation breaks international law and undermines modern slavery protections.

The number of small boat arrivals this year now stands at 8,858, compared with 10,138 at the same point last year.

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly mentions the United Nations and its role in reporting on displaced people, matching the description, but the taxonomy does not include a specific label for an intergovernmental organization, so the best fit is "Other".

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly references the "United Nations" and its agency "United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)". The mention of the UN as a global intergovernmental body headquartered in New York City aligns perfectly with the Wikidata entity’s name, description, and key properties. No conflicting information is present, confirming the entity’s presence and identity.
reasoning.statement_assessment: The article attributes statements to the United Nations: it reports that the UN "warned that 110 million people globally have been displaced" and that the UNHCR "said in a new report that numbers had surged by more than 20 million". These are clear attributions of statements to the entity.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the United Nations, as an intergovernmental organization, to issue warnings about global displacement, and for its specialized agency UNHCR to publish displacement statistics. The statements are consistent with the UN’s mandate and typical public communications.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions or conflicting details were found between the article’s content and the Wikidata profile of the United Nations.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly mentions "The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)" and attributes statements to it, confirming the target entity is present.
reasoning.statement_detection: UNHCR is quoted as saying in a new report that numbers have surged, and later that the UK was one of 92 countries with an asylum backlog. These are clear statements attributed to the entity.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q50357027 is an organization named "United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees" with alias "UN Refugee Agency", matching the target name and description. It is the only candidate whose type is an organization (the target type). Candidate Q61931977 is a government agency, which does not align with the target type. Therefore Q50357027 is the best match.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q50357027 represents the UNHCR, a UN agency that regularly publishes reports and statistics on displacement. It has the appropriate authority to make the statements cited.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: The statements about global displacement figures and country-specific asylum backlogs are within the UNHCR’s mandate, making the attribution highly plausible.
reasoning.final_justification: Q50357027 satisfies all critical identification criteria (name, type, alias) and is the most plausible source for the quoted statements. The entity is present and making statements, so the chosen Wikidata ID is for both presence and attribution.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "Lib Dem peer Baroness Ludford" and quotes her speaking in the House of Lords. This matches the Wikidata entity Sarah Ludford, Baroness Ludford, who is a Liberal Democrat peer and member of the House of Lords. The name, title, and political affiliation align perfectly, confirming the entity’s presence and identity.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Baroness Ludford is quoted directly: "When we do try to do it we are abused, bullied and intimidated as we were until 4.20am last Thursday," and she also comments that the package had received "almost no scrutiny" in the Commons. These are clear statements attributed to her.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for a Liberal Democrat peer in the House of Lords to speak on immigration legislation and to criticize government measures. The context of the debate and her role support the plausibility of her statements.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions are found between the article’s depiction of Baroness Ludford and the Wikidata profile. The political party, title, and setting all match.

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article quotes Lord Hodgson, identifying him as a Tory peer, which matches both the name and the description provided.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article refers to a contemporary Tory peer named "Lord Hodgson" who is quoted in the House of Lords debate. The Wikidata entity provided is Brian Houghton Hodgson (1800/1801‑1894), a 19th‑century British diplomat and naturalist with no connection to the modern peerage. The name, time period, occupation, and political affiliation do not match. Therefore the Wikidata entity is not present in the article.
reasoning.statement_assessment: N/A – the entity is not identified.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: The article’s Lord Hodgson is a living Tory peer; the Wikidata entry describes a deceased naturalist and diplomat from the 1800s. This fundamental mismatch rules out identity.
